docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, May 4 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, supported by George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, asked Congress today for a "standstill" of one year on tariff legislation to give the Eisenhower Administration time to evolve a...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 4 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, supported by George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, asked Congress today for a "standstill" of one year on tariff legislation to give the Eisenhower Administration time to evolve a national foreign trade policy consonant with current world conditions.

headline.main: DULLES, HUMPHREY ASK TARIFFS AWAIT NEW TRADE POLICY; ' Standstill' Is Urged on House With Trade Act Extension -- Simpson Bill Is Opposed

docs.snippet: Hides, wool, zinc, coffee and cottonseed oil showed increased activity yesterday on New York commodity exchanges.

headline.main: RUBBER AND COCOA REGISTER DECLINES; Potatoes, Wool, Coffee, Sugar and Hides Futures Advance in Commodity Markets

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, announced today that an additional duty of 18 per cent would be put on Uruguayan wool tops about June 15. There is already a duty of 27 3/4 cents per pound and 6 1/4 per cent on...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, announced today that an additional duty of 18 per cent would be put on Uruguayan wool tops about June 15. There is already a duty of 27 3/4 cents per pound and 6 1/4 per cent on wool tops.
docs.abstract: duty raised 18%, effective about June 15; trade reaction

headline.main: DUTY RISE PLANNED ON WOOL TOPS SOON; Countervailing Levy of 18% to Be Imposed About June 15 on Uruguayan Imports

docs.snippet: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 8 -President Eisenhower today won the full endorsement of top business leaders in his demands that a balanced budget precede any reductions in taxes. Members of the Business Advisory Council, called together to advise the...
docs.lead_paragraph: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 8 -President Eisenhower today won the full endorsement of top business leaders in his demands that a balanced budget precede any reductions in taxes. Members of the Business Advisory Council, called together to advise the Secretary of Commerce on economic affairs, conceded t hat even the excess profits tax, due to expire June 30, should be kept in force until other sources of revenue sufficient to meet Government costs were uncovered.

headline.main: EISENHOWER BACKED ON HIS TAX STAND; The Business Advisory Council Endorses View That Budget Balance Must Precede Cut

docs.snippet: MOTHERS are no less popular than before. At any rate, Mother's Day business in New York and Brooklyn department stores this year went ahead of last year's by a small margin, despite poor weather at the beginning of the week.
docs.lead_paragraph: MOTHERS are no less popular than before. At any rate, Mother's Day business in New York and Brooklyn department stores this year went ahead of last year's by a small margin, despite poor weather at the beginning of the week.

docs.snippet: Weakness in the Canadian dollar and British pound sterling were the main points of interest in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Amount of business transacted was reported to be fairly heavy at each daily session.

headline.main: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES; Week Ended May 8, 1953

docs.snippet: The recent decision by the Treasury Department to increase duties on imports of wool tops from Uruguary, because that country's multiple currency exchange rates are considered a subsidy device, has drawn criticism from foreign traders here.
docs.lead_paragraph: The recent decision by the Treasury Department to increase duties on imports of wool tops from Uruguary, because that country's multiple currency exchange rates are considered a subsidy device, has drawn criticism from foreign traders here.
docs.abstract: traders attack US Sec Humphrey for duty rise on Uruguayan wool tops

headline.main: TRADERS CRITICIZE RISE IN WOOL DUTY; Action Is Called 'Unfortunate' Because of Damage Seen to Latin-American Relations

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, May 16 -- A plot to assassinate President Juan Peron last Wednesday morning was frustrated as a result of the police arrests of suspected terrorists, Dr. Miguel Vignola, national judge in charge of the investigation of the recent acts...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, May 16 -- A plot to assassinate President Juan Peron last Wednesday morning was frustrated as a result of the police arrests of suspected terrorists, Dr. Miguel Vignola, national judge in charge of the investigation of the recent acts of violence, announced today.
docs.abstract: Dr Vignola repts arrests of terrorist suspects thwarted May 16 'plot' to kill Peron; charges link with exiles in Uruguay; Oligarchs' warned; Duperial Chem Industries woman worker questioned

headline.main: PLOT TO KILL PERON LAID TO TERRORISTS; Argentine Judge Tells of Plans to Assassinate Leader on Morning of May 13
